Award.AwardTitle: New Applications for Atom Interferometry using Material Nano-Gratings
Award.AbstractNarration:
An atom interferometer will be used as an ultra-sensitive tool for measuring perturbations to atomic motion. Laser beams usually attract or repel atoms, but this project will identify wavelengths of light that leave atoms unperturbed. Measuring these so-called "tune-out wavelengths" with unprecedented sub-picometer accuracy will serve as a benchmark test for sophisticated atomic structure calculations. This work will establish measurements of tune-out wavelengths as a novel way to test calculations that are needed to support atomic clocks, quantum computation, and atomic parity violation studies.

The broader impacts include training students to pioneer new applications for atom optics. Atom optics refers to the art of manipulating atomic de Broglie waves, much like ordinary light waves, by reflection, refraction, and diffraction. This project also teaches students to use nanotechnology, such as nanostructure diffraction gratings that serve as beam splitters for atoms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wave-particle duality is one of the most profound concepts that emerged from the development of quantum physics. Atom interferometry, representing an important realization of this concept, has found numerous applications. Examples include precision measurements of gravity, time and frequency, fine structure constant, atomic dipole matrix elements, polarizabilities etc. We developed new approaches for atom interferometry to improve the existing measurements of atomic polarizabilities. The precision measurements of polarizabilities are necessary to address significant problems in atomic physics related to atomic clocks, atomic parity non-conservation, quantum many-body theory, and quantum control.

We used atom interferometry to measure the ground state polarizability of Potassium, Rubidium, and Cesium atoms with highest accuracy reported so far. Nano-gratings were an enabling technology in this work. In a new application of atom interferometry, we measured the wavelengths of light that cause zero ac-Stark shift for ground-state atoms. These are called “magic-zero” or “tune-out” wavelengths. By developing a new technique of decoherence spectroscopy, we measured the tune-out wavelengths with unprecedented accuracy. Decoherence due to photon scattering in an atom interferometer was studied as a function of laser frequency near an atomic resonance. The longest tune-out wavelength for potassium atoms was measured to be 768.9701(4) nm. We discovered how the earth's rotation rate can affect tune-out wavelengths made with an atom interferometer. Using femtosecond lasers, we also conducted measurements of light-induced couplings in the excited states of atoms. These results elucidate the dynamic nature of electronic structure in the presence of light fields and offer opportunities to control the atomic properties.

Magic-zero wavelength results we obtained are a novel way to study atomic dipole matrix elements. Our measurements will test atomic structure calculations and pave the path for improving the accuracy of atomic clocks. Precise and accurate experimental measurements in this field are crucial because calculating these atomic and molecular properties ab initio is challenging and requires modeling of quantum many-body systems with relativistic corrections. Furthermore, the atom-surface interaction measurements test quantum electrodynamics calculations that include atomic core electrons and realistic surfaces.

Under the educational objectives of this program, apart from creating opportunities for the graduate students to accomplish new research, we worked to increase the participation of undergraduate students in research projects that lie on the frontiers of physics. Collectively, the precision measurements and new techniques developed here advance the art of atom interferometry. It is envisioned that atom interferometer-based measurements could even become useful for studying gravitational waves, freefall of antimatter, terrestrial dark energy, and atom neutrality.
